title: Genealogy and Birth of Christ
shortSummary: Matthew chapter 1 presents the genealogy of Jesus Christ, tracing His lineage from Abraham through David to Joseph, affirming His rightful place in Jewish history and prophecy. The chapter concludes with the miraculous birth of Jesus, emphasizing His divine conception and fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.
timeline: c. 2000 BC - Abraham to c. 4 BC - Birth of Jesus Christ

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The promised Messiah, Son of God and Son of David, whose genealogy and miraculous birth are recorded in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Joseph
keyCharacters.description: The husband of Mary, a just man who obediently accepts the divine message about Jesus' conception and takes Mary as his wife.

keyCharacters.name: Mary
keyCharacters.description: The virgin mother of Jesus, chosen by God to bear the Messiah through the Holy Ghost.

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch of Israel, from whom Jesus’ genealogy begins, highlighting the fulfillment of God’s covenant promises.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The king of Israel, an ancestor of Jesus, establishing Jesus’ royal lineage as the Son of David.

definitions.definition: A biblical term meaning 'to father' or 'to be the ancestor of,' used in genealogies to indicate direct descent.
A formal engagement or betrothal, a legally binding promise of marriage in Jewish culture.
The third Person of the Trinity, God’s Spirit, who miraculously causes the conception of Jesus in Mary.
A Hebrew name meaning 'God with us,' signifying Jesus’ divine presence among His people.

outline.heading: Genealogy of Jesus Christ
outline.description: This section traces the lineage of Jesus from Abraham to Joseph, emphasizing His legal right to the throne of David and fulfilling prophecy about the Messiah’s ancestry.

outline.heading: Announcement of Jesus’ Birth
outline.description: The narrative introduces Mary’s miraculous conception by the Holy Ghost and Joseph’s initial righteous response to this unexpected situation.

outline.heading: Divine Assurance to Joseph
outline.description: An angel appears to Joseph in a dream, reassuring him to take Mary as his wife and revealing the divine purpose of Jesus’ birth as Savior.

outline.heading: Fulfillment of Prophecy
outline.description: Matthew highlights that Jesus’ birth fulfills Isaiah’s prophecy of a virgin bearing a son named Emmanuel, confirming Jesus as God with us.

outline.heading: Joseph’s Obedience
outline.description: Joseph obeys the angel’s command, taking Mary as his wife and naming the child Jesus, demonstrating faithful submission to God’s plan.

application: Trust God’s timing and plan even when circumstances seem difficult or confusing, as Joseph did with Mary’s pregnancy.
Recognize Jesus as the fulfillment of God’s promises and the Savior who came to save us from our sins.
Obey God’s instructions promptly and faithfully, following Joseph’s example of righteous action.
Rejoice in the truth that God is with us (Emmanuel), providing comfort and assurance in every season of life.

keyVerses.text: And she shall bring forth a son, and thou shalt call his name JESUS: for he shall save his people from their sins.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus’ divine mission as Savior, central to Christian faith.

keyVerses.text: Behold, a virgin shall be with child, and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us.
keyVerses.significance: It confirms the fulfillment of prophecy and the incarnation of God in Jesus Christ.

keyVerses.text: Then Joseph her husband, being a just man, and not willing to make her a publick example, was minded to put her away privily.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Joseph’s righteousness and mercy, setting an example of godly character.

keyVerses.text: And knew her not till she had brought forth her firstborn son: and he called his name JESUS.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the virgin birth and Joseph’s obedience in naming Jesus, affirming His identity.
